The ideal education system, in my view, is one that functions as a crucible of merit and efficiency. It must be designed not to coddle or accommodate every deviation, but to identify and nurture the most capable minds so that they may serve as the engines of progress. The goal is not universal inclusion for its own sake, but the cultivation of a society where talent rises unimpeded and where resources are invested in those who will most effectively leverage them.

In practice, this means a system that prioritizes academic rigor, measurable outcomes, and early identification of potential. It must be stratified—yes, stratified—to channel resources toward those who demonstrate initiative, discipline, and aptitude. The notion that every child must be given the same tools and the same amount of time to succeed is a recipe for mediocrity. Instead, we should redirect support to high-achieving students who will contribute meaningfully to innovation, industry, and governance.

As for those whose cognitive or physical abilities fall outside the standard range, I believe it is both unrealistic and inefficient to integrate them into the mainstream educational framework. Special accommodations, while well-intentioned, often dilute the quality of instruction and divert resources from those who can and will use them to their fullest. A separate, streamlined system—focused on basic literacy, life skills, and vocational training—would be more practical. It would prevent the dilution of the primary system and ensure that those with the greatest potential are not held back by the limitations of others.

I am not suggesting that those with disabilities be ignored. I am suggesting that we apply the same logic we use in other areas of resource allocation: prioritize where impact is greatest. Society has finite resources, and if we are to maximize our collective potential, we must be willing to make difficult choices. That is the essence of efficiency. That is the foundation of a truly meritocratic system.
